narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: close reading, analytical thinking, writing, theoretical and philosophical ideas of space and the different ways in which we occupy them

I developed an aptitude to interpreting space as a flexible variable- an element that one can mould to fit in not just into physics but to the extent of feminism. This course has sharpened my analytical skills and provided me with a thorough trajectory of the different perspectives on the concept of space.
Definitely learned a lot about architectural theory, but also how to apply philosophical modes of thought to the study of art history -- which is an immensely useful skill.

This course explored interpretations and discussions of the concept of space at the intersection of art history, critical theory, and philosophy. We began with philosophical foundations on definitions of space, which were threaded as recurring themes throughout our discussions of space in practice--namely, in architecture and art. I learned not only about different methods of conceptualizing space, but also about applying these frameworks to concrete contexts. Thinking spatially and about space's significance provides a rich lens through which to interpret art, architecture, and daily activities.

This course is one of the most interesting courses I have taken at Yale. While I am not an art or architecture major, this course has given me insights into how to visualize and understand what space means. It gave me the skills to question why our surrounding spaces are the way they are and what impact it has on our lives. I am not exaggerating when I say that when I walk down the street or enter a building, I feel differently about the space and more cognizant about my surroundings. Professor Buckley does a great job trying to convey these themes and questions that let us challenge our conceptions of space.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
A strength of the course is definitely in Professor Buckley who is extremely insightful. The way he talks about complicated readings and concepts make it easy to understand and digest. Every seminar was interesting and it was fun to engage in discussion since he posed very thought-provoking questions. Readings were also interesting and there was a good mix of different types of reading (philosophical, historical, architectural, etc.). I also think the class transitioned to online learning very well and was conducive to online leaning because the small seminar allowed me to stay engaged throughout the semester.

One weakness might be how some of the philosophical readings were very difficult to understand so some background or a synopsis of it prior to reading would have been helpful. The overview was always given in the next class, but maybe getting some background in the previous class would have been helpful.
This is a very strong class. It shapes the ideas of space. In my opinion it should also be a part of the regular YSoA courses for architecture students.

strengths: interesting weekly topics, thought provoking assignments. 
weaknesses: honestly none. I loved this class and thought it was very well designed and executed.

The texts and discussions were incredibly interesting every week. Each presented new and interesting perspectives. We did journaling exercises frequently in class, which I found incredibly helpful to thinking through ideas and contributing to discussion on weighty topics.
While I liked that student presentations could guide discussions each week, I think I might also have benefited from more structured guidance with the readings. They were often long, dense pieces, which while interesting, could become a bit tedious without guidance. At the same time, though, I think Prof. Buckley's MO of encouraging students to take charge of the discussion created a comfortable environment for everyone to participate as they felt comfortable.
Great content. Quality peers (I found, luckily.) Engaging material. You make it what you want.

The course is constructed very well with a well-designed syllabus. Furthermore, the readings are not too difficult or too long to tackle. To improve the engagement during the seminars (which I believe was somewhat limited due to the virtual format) I would recommend that both the professor and students talk about examples of spaces or objects beyond just the readings or object presentations to expand the breadth of discussion.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was very conducive to learning virtually/remotely because it was a small class and you had to engage in discussion. Also, the assignments were mostly individual writing assignments so that is easy to do yourself as opposed to labs/group projects that require more in person work.
Prof. Buckley has been very understanding and supportive the entire course. The combination of theory and dialogue sessions was a good way to learn better.

Using Perusall for readings was interesting. I think it was nice to be able to read and comment on readings prior to discussing as a class.
I found it difficult to look at the screen for 2 straight hours. For longer seminars, I think it would help to have some level of break in the middle of class, or to split class into two sessions.

This course adapted well to the virtual format but at times suffered some Zoom fatigue and awkward silences. I don't think this is a reflection of the course or Professor Buckley, but merely the virtual format. To address this, I recommend that both the professor and students talk about examples of spaces or objects beyond just the readings or object presentations to expand the breadth of discussion. This would allow for greater discussion on things that interest students and bring in their expertise from their various disciplines.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely recommend! Professor Buckley is so insightful and explains difficult ideas in a way that I could understand. Also, the readings were truly interesting and I actually enjoyed reading them. I looked forward to this class because it was a time we could discuss all our ideas and interpretations of the readings.
I'd highly recommend this course to all architecture undergraduates and graduates.
Yes! It's a wonderful course for those already interested in architecture and also for those looking to learn more in a really unique and engaging way. Also Prof Buckley is just the best.

Absolutely. This was one of the most interesting and engaging courses I have taken at Yale, and I only wish I could have taken it in person. But, amidst a pandemic semester that made it difficult to focus on anything, this was the one class I consistently wanted to engage with and participate in. It combines philosophy and art history to deconstruct the idea of space, what it means, how we occupy it, how we leverage it in art and architecture. It genuinely impacted the way I feel I inhabit and pay attention to the spaces and places in my life. Prof. Buckley is brilliant, kind, and engaging in discussion, and he places high value on student contributions. In my experience as a student outside of the art history department, I've found it a bit difficult to feel at home in art history environments, especially at higher level courses--but I didn't feel that here at all. I found the class comfortable and engaging, and I truly enjoyed exploring ideas in the class.
Yes. Have fun!

I would highly recommend this course to another student at Yale, especially if you are not an art/architecture person. The concepts and lessons learned are very helpful in all aspects of life and Professor Buckley has many thought-provoking questions on the topic. Furthermore, this class would only be strengthened with in-person interaction and instruction.
